review.title: A Short Review of Ethical Challenges in Clinical Natural Language Processing
review.abstract: Clinical NLP has an immense potential in contributing to how clinical practice will be revolutionized by the advent of large scale processing of clinical records. However, this potential has remained largely untapped due to slow progress primarily caused by strict data access policies for researchers. In this paper, we discuss the concern for privacy and the measures it entails. We also suggest sources of less sensitive data. Finally, we draw attention to biases that can compromise the validity of empirical research and lead to socially harmful applications.
histories: First Workshop on Ethics in Natural Language Processing (EACL'17)
review.COMMENTS: First Workshop on Ethics in Natural Language Processing (EACL'17)

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 3.10 090v 1 [cs.C L] 29 Mar 201 7contributes to how clinical practice is being revolutionised by the advent of large-scale processing of clinical records. However, this potential has largely gone untapped due to slow progress caused primarily by strict data access policies for researchers. In this paper, we discuss concerns about privacy and associated measures. We also propose sources of less sensitive data. Finally, we draw attention to distortions that can affect the validity of empirical research and lead to socially harmful applications.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The use of notes written by healthcare providers in clinical settings has long been recognized as a source of valuable information for clinical practice and medical research, and access to large volumes of clinical reports can be helpful in identifying causes of disease, identifying diagnoses, identifying side effects of beneficial treatments, and monitoring clinical outcomes (Agus, 2016; Goldacre, 2014; Murdoch and Detsky, 2013).The goal of natural language clinical processing (NLP) is to develop and apply computerized methods for linguistic analysis and knowledge extraction from free text reports (Demner-Fushman et al., 2009; Hripcsak et al., 1995; Meystre et al., 2008).However, while the benefits of clinical NLP and data collection have been widely recognized, progress in developing clinical NLP techniques has been slow. Several factors contributing to this have been identified, notably difficult access to data, limited collaboration between researchers from different groups, and little biological sharing.

sections.heading: 2 Sensitivity of data and privacy
sections.text: This year it has come to the point where it will be able to put itself at the top, "he said." We have to put ourselves at the top, "he said." We have to put ourselves at the top, "he said." We have to put ourselves at the top, "he said." We have to put ourselves at the top, "he said.

sections.heading: 2.1 Protecting the individual
sections.text: In fact, you will be able to put yourself in a situation where you put yourself in the centre, in which you put yourself in the centre.

sections.heading: 3 Social impact and biases
sections.text: The question, therefore, is what are the most important clinical biases and how to overcome them, not only from ethical but also from legal responsibility. Regarding the issue of bias, which we have referred to in this section as algorithm transparency (Goodman, 2016; Kamarinou et al., 2016), this right to explanation requires that influences of bias be presented in training data. In addition to this bias, which we have introduced in Section 2, we will discuss other sources of bias in this section. Unlike bias, which is a bias at the corpus level, these biases are already present in documents here, and therefore difficult to take into account by introducing larger companies.Data quality text produced in clinical settings does not always tell a complete or accurate patient history (e.g. due to time constraints or the treatment of patients in different hospitals, decisions).

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Difficult access to data due to privacy concerns has been an obstacle to progress in this area. We have discussed how the protection of privacy through remediation measures and the requirement for informed consent can impact work in this area. Perhaps it is time to rethink the right to privacy in the health sector in the light of recent work on the ethics of big data, particularly its uneasy relationship with the right to science, i.e. the ability to benefit from and participate in science (Tasioulas, 2016; Verbeek, 2014). We have also addressed possible sources of bias that may have implications for the application of NLP in the health sector and that may ultimately lead to unfair or harmful treatment.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Madhumita and the anonymous reviewers for their useful comments. Part of this research was carried out as part of the Accumulate IWT SBO project, which is funded by the State Agency for Innovation by Science and Technology (IWT).

Here, consent can be presumed either in a broad manner— allowing unspecified future research, subject to ethical restrictions—or a tiered manner— allowing certain areas of research but not others (Mittelstadt and Floridi, 2016; Terry, 2012).

Additionaly, it may be due to organizational skepticism about the effectiveness of sanitization techniques, although it has been shown that automated de-identification systems for English perform on par with manual de-identification (Deleger et al., 2013).

We also believe that a distinction between academic research and commercial use of clinical data should be implemented, as the public is more willing to allow research than commercial exploitation (Lawrence, 2016; van Staa et al., 2016).

Secure access Since withholding data from researchers would be a dubious way of ensuring confidentiality (Berman, 2002), the research has long been active on secure access and storage of sensitive clinical data, and the balance between the degree of privacy loss and the degree of utility.

Secure access Since withholding data from researchers would be a dubious way of ensuring confidentiality (Berman, 2002), the research has long been active on secure access and storage of sensitive clinical data, and the balance between the degree of privacy loss and the degree of utility. This is a broad topic that is outside the scope of this article. The interested reader can find the relevant information in Dwork and Pottenger (2013), Malin et al.

This is a broad topic that is outside the scope of this article. The interested reader can find the relevant information in Dwork and Pottenger (2013), Malin et al. (2013) and Rindfleisch (1997).

metadata.abstractText: Clinical NLP has an immense potential in contributing to how clinical practice will be revolutionized by the advent of large scale processing of clinical records. However, this potential has remained largely untapped due to slow progress primarily caused by strict data access policies for researchers. In this paper, we discuss the concern for privacy and the measures it entails. We also suggest sources of less sensitive data. Finally, we draw attention to biases that can compromise the validity of empirical research and lead to socially harmful applications.
